numbered_ace_sentences: 1. For every row, the percentage of young women was greater than the percentage of young men.
2. This difference is likely due to several factors.
3. One factor is that some parents are more protective of their daughters than of their sons.
4. Many responses may be from young adults.
5. Some parents require these young adults to call or text at least once a week.
6. I wonder if there is a difference between teenagers and people in their thirties.
7. The survey targeted people who are at least 18 years old and at most 34 years old.
8. This age range is a large gap.
9. I am interested in how getting older affects how often a person reaches out to his or her parents.
10. There are many ways to categorize this data.
11. One way is whether a person is in college or not in college.
12. One way is whether a person is taken or single.
13. One way is whether a person lives in a different time zone or in the same time zone as the parents.
14. I wonder if the survey counted reaching out when a young adult only responded to a previous text from a parent.
15. The term reaching out is ambiguous.
16. The term reaching out is especially ambiguous for texting.
17. I call my parents at least once a week.
18. I text my parents very often throughout the week.
19. I do not visit my parents because of the distance.
20. My behavior aligns with the data.
21. A possible title is: C'mon, they deserve a call.
